description: Inherited from Middle English ryngbon; equivalent to ring +‎ bone.

entries.meaning: osteoarthritis affecting any of several bones of a horse's foot
examples: “As an inventor,” Bob Mason suggested, “you're a howling success at shooting craps ! If I were as free of spavins, ringbone, saddle-galls, and splints as you are, I'd have that nanny-goat in here, hog-tie her, flop her and let the boy help himself.  […] ”
